rComments: ishibashi sensei tries to be sweet and nice on the outside, but she is really just plain mean. she's moody and takes it out on her students all the time. she's unfair and subjective in everything, from lecture to grading. also very mean when answering questions, makes personal attacks. i stopped taking japanese because of her!
she's a cute old lady, but not the best of teachers. very "traditional Japanese" teacher, as i've experienced and others have said. but it doesn't keep her from being a cute old lady.

Professor Ishibashi is undoubtedly the worst professor I have ever had the misfortune to study under.  She wasn't clear about what she wanted us to learn and much of the class consisted of her talking to us, in English, about unrelated subjects.  Professor Ishibashi is too old and senile to still be teaching, in my opinion.

Being that she is japanese she still has a lot to learn of the culture.  Perhaps she is hiding much of her heritage.  I took a class taught by her but realized that I learned more of the truth from my family's Japanese (Okinawan) heritage, which I must say that she had no respect for.

Having her in Japanese 1 helped a lot in preparation for having her again in Japanese 5. She is very nice, and though her teaching style is considered "old-fashioned," you will still learn in her class. Unlike Fujita, she mostly concentrates on grammar and sentence structures in literature.
She is a very nice teacher in class, but is not a very helpful, informative teacher. AYou must rely on the book to learn the course. I recommened all students stay away.

Ishibashi is a horrible teacher.  You must rely on the book for learning japanese.  She is a really nice woman during class time, but many people failed this class who did not deserve that grade.  Try to stay away from this teacher.
I really liked her, she was very nice to me and i have learned a lot from her.

She has her favorite students that she is nice to and will pick on those that she does not like. She is also old-fashioned and I did not learn much in her class. If you speak Japanese, she will expect more of you and will grade you harder.

Ishibashi-sensei's classes are based on reading and do not improve conversation skills. The books have various stories like art, folk lore, and the history of writing. She is a forgiving grader but many students do not like her old-fashioned style.

Ishibashi sensei is very selective of who she wants to be nice to.  All other professors in the language studies dept. was excellent, she was the exception and has left a bad taste in my mouth whenever the topic UCSC comes up even 5 years later.

Ishibashi's teaching style is thouroughly uninspiring.  I have seen many people with alot of enthusiasm for the language become deadened and jaded as a result of her teaching style.  She is a nice woman, to be sure, but her pedagogy is seriously lacking.

Ishibashi Sensei is a nice old Japanese lady who has a fairly old fashioned teaching style.  The reader we used for instace was quite dated, and there is a lot of rote reading and such in class.  Japanese is tough to learn, and she doesn't make it easier.
